<s>6th. Intersectionaries formed when a piece of plane glass 
is laid on a lens having a long focus, & therby producing a 
large set of Newtonian  rings; if the shadow of a Black card 
is thrown on the rings when the eye is at an elevation of 
about 30 degrees, a set of binary fringes will be seen 
drawn through the intersections of the primary set of rings 
with its reflected image, to an extent of seven or eight times 
the greatest diameter of the rings from which they are 
produced. These latter fringes differ from all the other 
phenomena, in being visible only at right angles to 
the direction of the light, whereas all the rest may be 
perceived in any other direction. 
If lenses are used instead of plane glass plates in any of 
the foregoing experiments, circular rings will be formed in-
stead of rectilinear phenomena. for example, if two lenses, 
or a flat glass & a lens are laid together, Newtonian rings 
will be formed; if a double convex lens  is placed between 
two pieces of plane glass so as to produce two sets of prim-
ary rings differing in dimensions, & so situated that the 
rings of each set shall interfere & cross each other, a set of 
intersectionary rings will be formed corresponding to the 
right lined diagonal fringes mentioned above as the fourth 
species of Binaries; & altho turned to rings, retaining 
the Binary characteristic through every variation 
of dimensions. 
It may be observed that in the above recapitulation 
the results are not placed in the same order in which 
the discoveries were made; because that in interrogating 
Nature by experiment on her secret operations, we 
must be content to receive her answers in that order 
in which our ignorance of her laws have placed 
them, altho that may not be the most advantageous 
for discovery; for instance, had primary fringes (which 
are supposed the most simple phenomena)  been first 
discovered; it must have been observed that any degree of 
bend or convexity in either plate of glass, would have 
produced a corresponding bend in the prismatic fringes 
formed between them; it would therfore have been 
an easy inference that globular surfaces must produce 
rings<\s>
